header.title: Data Suitability Assessment Tool

footer.copyright: © Statistics Canada - Data Suitability Assessment Tool.
footer.builtWith: Built with React
footer.symbolOfGovernmentOfCanada: Symbol of the Government of Canada

frontPage.intro: The Data Suitability Assessment Tool is mainly designed to help assess if non-official data are considered fit for purpose to contribute to Canada's reporting on the Sustainable Development Goals (<abbr>SDGs</abbr>), but it can also be used to evaluate data for any other purposes.
frontPage.assessmentInfo: Through this tool, data suitability is assessed by evaluating both the quality and the ethics of the data.

bulletPoints.item1: Data ethics assess whether the data have been acquired and used appropriately throughout their life cycle, which spans from the acquisition to the dissemination.
bulletPoints.item2: Data quality is important as it helps evaluate the measures in place to safeguard the data against errors and inform users of their fitness for purpose.
bulletPoints.label: Assessment criteria list

frontPage.usage: If you wish to pursue the assessment of your data for a potential SDG reporting, please contact us with your submission once the data have been evaluated with this tool.
frontPage.noteToUsers: Please note that this Data Suitability Assessment Tool is not meant to assess if the data meet official statistics standards.
frontPage.contactInfo: Do not hesitate to contact Statistics Canada's SDG team should you have any questions.

intro.intro: Statistics Canada's core data ethics principles for data collection, editing and dissemination are evaluated through the following five elements:
intro.part1: Evaluating each of these elements helps us assess if the data are used appropriately throughout its life cycle and can therefore be considered suitable for the purpose of contributing to Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) reporting. Please consult Statistics Canada's Trust Center to learn more about data ethics.
intro.part2: Each ethic principle is evaluated below by answering if the data are aligned with the principles or not.

results.title: Results of the Data Ethics Assessment:
results.passMessage: As evaluated above, the data are considered fit for purpose for <abbr title="Sustainable Development Goals">SDG</abbr> reporting.
results.failMessage: As evaluated above, the data are not considered fit for purpose for SDG reporting. To learn more about and improve on data ethics and data quality, please refer to Statistics Canada's Trust Center.

alerts.answerAll: Please provide answers to all criteria.

validation.errorSummaryTitle: The form could not be submitted because there are errors.

intro.intro: The following Statistics Canada's data quality dimensions are used to assess the quality of data:
intro.part1: Evaluating each of these dimensions helps assess what was done to the data during the acquisition and processing, as well as how the data are made available. This evaluation provides an assessment of the methods in place to protect against errors and inform and give confidence in the quality of the data to users.
intro.part2: Each quality dimension is evaluated below by assessing if the data satisfy the criterion, and by selecting the checkbox for each satisfied criteria/criterion.

tooltip.title: Points correspond to the number of criteria satisfied:
tooltip.exceptions: Please note that the 'Accessibility and clarity' dimension contains only 2 criteria; satisfying both criteria (2/2) results in the maximum score of 3 points.

summary.title: Results of the Data Quality Assessment:

interpretation.low: As evaluated above, the quality of the data is not considered fit for purpose for SDG reporting. To learn more about and improve on data ethics and data quality, please refer to Statistics Canada's Trust Center.
interpretation.medium: As evaluated above, the quality of the data is considered fit for purpose for SDG reporting but could be improved. To learn more about and improve on data ethics and data quality, please refer to Statistics Canada's Trust Center.
interpretation.high: As evaluated above, the quality of the data is considered fit for purpose for <abbr title="Sustainable Development Goals">SDG</abbr> reporting.
interpretation.fail: As evaluated above, the quality of the data is not considered fit for purpose for SDG reporting. To learn more about and improve on data ethics and data quality, please refer to Statistics Canada's Trust Center.

actions.goBackARIA: Go back to the previous section

validation.errorSummaryTitle: The form could not be submitted because there are errors.
validation.atLeastOneCriterion: Please select at least one criterion for each quality dimension.

messages.bothPass: As evaluated, the data are considered fit for purpose for <abbr title="Sustainable Development Goals">SDG</abbr> reporting.
messages.ethicsFailQualityPass: As evaluated, the data are not considered fit for purpose for SDG reporting. The data must satisfy all core data ethics principles to be suitable for SDG reporting. To learn more about and improve on data ethics and data quality, please refer to Statistics Canada's Trust Center.
messages.ethicsPassQualityFail: As evaluated, the data are not considered fit for purpose for SDG reporting. The data must obtain a minimum score of 8 on the assessment against the dimensions of quality criteria. To learn more about and improve on data ethics and data quality, please refer to Statistics Canada's Trust Center.
messages.bothFail: As evaluated, the data are not considered fit for purpose for SDG reporting. To learn more about and improve on data ethics and data quality, please refer to Statistics Canada's Trust Center.

export.title: Export Assessment
export.description: Please select a format to export your assessment results. You may preview the text and CSV options before proceeding with the download.
export.formatHelp: Please select the preferred format for exporting your assessment results.
export.pdfPreview: A PDF report will be generated when you click Download.
export.wordPreview: A Word document report will be generated when you click Download.

principle1.explanation: The information acquired and utilized must provide a clear and easily communicated benefit to Canadians. The data must support Canada's reporting on the Sustainable Development Goals (<abbr>SDGs</abbr>) by enabling the measurement of an unreported indicator or by providing more granular data for an indicator already reported.
principle1.criteria: Does the information provide a clear benefit to Canadians?

principle2.explanation: Data that include potentially sensitive topics require a dissemination plan to alleviate any potential harm, unfairness or risk of amplifying stereotypes and stigma on groups featured in the data. Additionally, the appropriate partners should be consulted throughout the process to discuss any potential fairness and harm issues. The data must use the appropriate terminology and categories to describe the various population groups featured.
principle2.criteria: Are potentially sensitive topics handled in a way that ensures fairness and causes no harm?

principle3.explanation: The methods used to transform the information to produce statistics must be communicated clearly to ensure transparency. The methodology used must be documented and continually monitored alongside its outputs to ensure continued robustness and relevance for the reporting.
principle3.criteria: Are the methods used understood, monitored and communicated regularly alongside its outputs?

principle4.explanation: Protecting the privacy of respondents throughout the statistical process is critical. Privacy refers to the right of the respondent to decide how their personal data are collected and used. The privacy of respondents must be maintained during all the steps of the statistical process.
principle4.criteria: Is the privacy of respondents respected?

principle5.explanation: Ensuring that the data do not contain confidential information, such as personal information or identifying characteristics is critical to ensuring confidentiality. Some examples of methods that can help include limiting access to confidential information to a need to know basis while limiting collection to strictly necessary information from fully consenting individuals.

dimension1.definition: The accuracy of statistical information is the degree to which the information correctly describes the phenomena it was designed to measure. Reliability reflects the degree to which statistical information correctly describes the phenomena it was designed to measure consistently over time. The data must accurately and reliably measure Canada's progress for a selected <abbr title="Sustainable Development Goals">SDG</abbr> indicator over time.
criteria: There are no or few missing values.
There are established verification rules for data validation.
Documented quality assurance processes were followed.

dimension2.definition: The timeliness of statistical information refers to the delay between the information reference period and the date on which the information becomes available. Punctuality refers to the difference between planned and actual availability. The data must provide a measure of Canada's progress on the <abbr title="Sustainable Development Goals">SDGs</abbr> at planned and regular intervals through time covering the period of the Agenda 2030.
criteria: Data are available in a timely manner.
Data are released at regular intervals.
Data are published on planned dates.

dimension3.definition: The accessibility and clarity of data and supporting information refer to the ease with which users can learn that the information exists, find it, view it and use it. The data and their supporting information must be easily accessible and harvested to facilitate its use in Canada's reporting on the <abbr title="Sustainable Development Goals">SDGs</abbr>.
criteria: Data and supporting information are easily accessible.
Data and supporting information are provided in an easy-to-use format.

dimension4.definition: The interpretability of statistical information refers to the availability of accompanying information needed to interpret the data and possibly reproduce it. This information normally covers the underlying concepts, the reference period of the data, the variables, the classifications used as well as the methodology of the data collection and processing.
criteria: A description of the methods used to collect, process and analyze the data is available to users.
The definition of all variables, code sets and classifications used is provided to the users.
The reference period of the data is well defined and communicated.

dimension5.definition: The coherence and comparability of statistical information refer to the degree to which it can be reliably combined and compared with other statistical information and over time. The use of common concepts (e.g., terminology, classification, methodology etc.) are critical to ensuring coherence and facilitate its use in Canada's reporting on the <abbr title="Sustainable Development Goals">SDGs</abbr>.
criteria: Comparability is maintained over time and across regions.
Any inconsistencies or break in the time series are explained.
